body: Also added a commit removing the banner into the ps1 profile to the branch as it was during that process we found this bug.
Nice!  Does this mean this works on OS X now, or just that it should work soon?
I built and ran it on OS X last night :smile: However, I made some changes in `monad` that aren't quite tested on OS X yet... let me go do that.
Either way, that is supremely awesome!

Just tested, still working on OS X, and the majority of our Pester tests pass too. The native tests fail, but it's a failure of a test itself, not the library.

It also compiles on Windows, I'm just having to adjust our guards to get it running. I'm hopeful it'll be soon.
I think you've named this repo incorrectly ;)
I made a point about that actually, that the name was going to be a misnomer very soon :smiley:
Closing for #7
I'm just going to clean this up a bit, rebase, then ff merge.
looks good
Just noting that there's apparently a [CLI parser](https://github.com/dotnet/corefxlab/blob/master/src/System.CommandLine/README.md) we might want to use.
@palladia Got master reset, want to rebase `dev/debug` and open a new PR?

Wrote a small tool to assist with doing this over the weekend. I'll test the VSO issues import on a private repo, run it by people, and then do the real deal. I expect to have this done in an hour or so.
:+1: Merging :smile:
:+1: Thanks! Merging.
Going to perform the import of VSO issues to GitHub tonight. If you don't want 400+ emails I would recommend temporarily setting GitHub settings to not email notifications.
PR'ed for the preview.
This is amazing. Also I _think_ I've found enough docs to enable this on a configuration basis, I will give it a whack!
:clap:

Now actually _using_ it causes a test failure:

```
Describing ConvertTo-SecureString
   Context Checking return types of ConvertTo-SecureString
    [-] Should return System.Security.SecureString after converting plaintext variable 70ms
      Unable to load DLL 'oleaut32.dll': The specified module could not be found.
       (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8007007E)
      at line: 6 in /home/powershell/workspace/monad-linux/test/powershell/ConvertTo-SecureString.Tests.ps1
```

But it satisfies build requirements.

So, the current "implementation" is a stub borrowed from @fearthecowboy (who I believe borrowed it from Mono).

What do we think the best thing is to do here, since `SecureString` isn't quite cross-platform?
Oh and you know what: there's a bad reason the package isn't super up-to-date, they did officially remove support for it (after having briefly added it). :cry:
Also while doing this, I'd like to use the `content` section to deploy the profile and ps1xml files, since it looks like it's now implemented.

We didn't end up importing last night as, after a conversation with GitHub support, we were pointed to an unreleased-but-available new API endpoint that allows bulk importing without sending 17,000+ emails and that will allow us to keep the original creation date and creator. @ealexjordan is updating the importer.

This should cause `./bin/powershell -c "exit 2"` to return 2 as the exit code now.

@zach-folwick Is there any way we could spawn a second PowerShell process using Pester to test this?

Yes, it's from mono https://github.com/mono/mono/blob/b7a308f660de8174b64697a422abfc7315d07b8c/mcs/class/corlib/System.Security/SecureString.cs 

According to @daxian-dbw it was a hack in a prototype to make it work. We really should be careful about legal implications. It should be possible to get code from CLR team.
